awd_titl_txt: New Developments in Methodology for Program Evaluation
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will develop new statistical methods for program evaluation with the goal of improving their reliability and scope in real-life applications. Program evaluation methods are widely used in a variety of disciplines in the social, behavioral, and biomedical sciences. These methods are empirically employed to determine the causal effect of a policy, intervention, or treatment on some outcome of interest. For example, program evaluation methods allow policy makers to improve social programs or public health officials to better target the mitigation of infectious diseases. This project will develop new identification, estimation, and inference results for three modern program evaluation methods: binscatter methods, synthetic control methods, and regression discontinuity methods. The results of this research will provide researchers with new methodological tools to improve empirical work. Graduate students will be mentored and trained in the new methodologies and provided with first-hand research experience. General-purpose software will be developed to implement the new methods.

This research project will provide new developments in mathematical statistics and econometrics. For binscatter methods, which are closely related to machine learning techniques, new uniform inference methods will be developed that build on strong approximation tools from probability theory. These results will provide valid confidence bands and hypothesis tests about shape restrictions for causal inference models with possibly heterogenous treatment effects. For synthetic control methods, novel prediction intervals will be developed using non-asymptotic probability concentration ideas from the high-dimensional statistical literature. Practical implementation of these prediction intervals based on the bootstrap also will be studied. For regression discontinuity designs, the project will develop new identification, estimation, inference, and falsification methods for settings with duration-type outcomes and allowing for covariate-adjustment and multiple cutoffs. Robust bias correction inference methods will be developed along with tuning parameter selection methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project aid in developing an array of tools for data analysis for public policy and program evaluation with focus on causal inference and treatment effect estimation. Main research output include: regression discontinuity design methods, synthetic controls methods, and binscatter methods. In addition, spin-off projects related to decision tree methods with applications to causal inference were developed as part of this grant. General purpose software and review articles were also produced to aid the dissemination of the new theory and methods developed as part of this grant. All aspects of the original proposals were completed, and three graduate students were trained as part of this research grant.

The main intellectual merit of this proposal was to developed novel theoretical results for three interconnected areas in program evaluation: binscatter methods, which are used for depicting large datasets as well as for estimating and testing heterogeneous treatment effects; synthetic control methods, which seek to estimate treatment effects of a single unit over time by using the evolution of control units in a pre-treatment period to generate a counterfactual (or synthetic) control outcome in the post-treatment period; and regression discontinuity methods, which exploit discontinuities in treatment assignment rules to estimate treatment effects. In each case, the grant developed new identification, estimation, inference and falsification methods, with theoretical foundations.

In terms of the broader Impacts of this grant, the proposed research program is interdisciplinary in nature, as the results applicable to many different fields of study. The grant offered researchers new methodological tools to improve empirical work. The grant developed general-purpose software, practical/scholastic general interest monographs, and trained multiple graduate students.

Altogether, this grant improved applied work and evidence-based policy-making developing novel theory and methods for modern program evaluation.

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2023
Modified by: Matias D Cattaneo
